column4: Hello everybody. I'm interested in building a new rig and I was wondering if anybody with a UEFI-based board has had trouble getting Ubuntu installed.
I've been kind of worried about being locked into a system where I can't disable secureboot.
that's unlikely to be an issue, even when they start shipping
I have seen a bunch of AMD boards with UEFI, wasn't sure if it had shipped. I suppose I should call the manufacturer just to make sure.
UEFI and secure boot aren't the same thing
neither are anything to be worried about
I understand that. I was asking because I know it's a feature that's supposed to ship with UEFI boards.
what were you asking, again?
I suppose what I was asking is if I am likely going to run into the secureboot issue with the UEFI boards that are already out.
you could but it's unlikely
what you'd want to keep an eye out is for things labelled 'Made for Microsoft Windows 8' or something to that effect
ahh, then that's good news.
to have such a boast associated with a product they're required to use secure boot
without such a boast they are under no such obligation to Microsoft
right, I know that the x86 certification program requires a way to get rid of it.
ahh, well I'm definitely avoiding the ARM hardware. I'm probably going to get an RPI or Beagleboard instead.
those are ARM, IIRC
oh :)
yeah, I don't mind ARM itself.
yeah you won't find any issues on such conscientious offerings
it'll just be Windows 8 tablets, some of them, and possibly some Apple ones in future
and of course it'll only be an issue before people figure out how to work around it :p
haha, well I suppose I'm not hedging my bets on it. I'd rather work with unencumbered software anyway, I'm playing around with OS dev, and I'd like to... you know... be able to boot my kernel, haha
I remember VIA working on a similar board, not sure how hacker friendly it's going to be.
